title-group.article-title: MONETARY DYNAMICS OF INFLATION: SOME EVIDENCE FOR A SMALL OPEN ECONOMY

abstract.p: The paper examines the empirical validity of the monetary theory of inflation for the small open economy of the United Arab Emirates over the last two decades. Besides the usual emphasis on the role of money-supply growth in the inflationary process, the theoretical model also incorporates the underlying money demand function to avoid possible misspecification. The results reveal several interesting policy implications. International monetary factors (represented primarily by world inflation) exert a significant impact upon the UAE inflation. Therefore, anti-inflation policies must take into account such foreign factors. However, the empirical results show that the effect of world prices on the UAE inflation is relatively dilute, with a small long-run elasticity. The central finding is that inflation in the UAE has its origin in domestic sources, particularly in excessive monetary expansions. There is decidedly strong evidence of a positive and significant impact of money-supply growth on inflation.
